dc:description:
WDR36 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant primary open angle glaucoma G in 2005 (Monemi et al., 2005, PMID: 15677485). The study reported linkage to WDR36 in 7 families with primary open angle glaucoma and identifed four variants that were predicted to be disease causing. However, the variants are not supported by functional evidence -- they are found at relatively high population frequencies in gnomAD. 

This gene-disease association has been studied in several case-control studies (PMID: 28658128, 29104481, 22025897, 18172102, 16723468, 19347049, 29540704, 17353431, 28282485, 19875670, 16876519); however, statistical significance was not reached in most. A meta-analysis (Liu et al, 2017; PMID: 28658128) including 5 individual studies reported no statistically significant association of WDR36 variants with primary open angle glaucoma.  

WDR36 is expressed ubiquitously, including th eye (PMID: 15677485). The function of WDR36 is not clearly understood, but animal studies suggest a role in eye development. Zebrafish and mouse models show head and eye phenotypes (PMID: 20631153, 18469340); however, they are non-specific and do not support the role of WDR36 variation in glaucoma. With an unclear role for this gene in glaucoma, it is thought to have a modifier effect in disease (PMID: 29104481). 

In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between WDR36 and autosomal dominant primary open angle glaucoma has been disputed and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role WDR36 plays in glaucoma, but based on the evidence avaialble at this time, the gene is disputed as a monogenic cause of glaucoma.
curationReasonDescription: The causal role of WDR36 variants in human disease is not clearly established. No human patients with glaucoma are reported in the literature to carry pathogenic/likely pathogenic variants in WDR36. Case-control studies do not show enrichment of variants in cases vs controls and a meta analysis revealed no statistical significance in the association of WDR36 variants with glaucoma. While studies in animal models show that WDR36 may have a functional role in eye development, none of the models develop the expected glaucoma phenotype. Based on these observations, the WDR36-primary open angle glaucoma gene-disease relationship is disputed.

evidence.dc:description: Authors report that the c.1805A>G p.Asp602Gly variant (likely benign in ClinVar) was identified in 13/670 cases and 0/476 controls in this study. This variant is reported at a frequency of 0.7% in non-Finnish European population (878/128738 alleles) with 4 homozygotes in gnomAD v2.1.1. This case report/variant is not scored as it appears to be too frequent in the general population to cause disease. (Note: the variant is reported in the paper as c.1973A>G, Asp658Gly.)

Authors report that the c.1177G>A p.Ala393Thr variant (likely benign/benign in ClinVar) was identified in 2/130 cases and 0/200 controls in this study. This variant is reported at a frequency of 4% in South Asian population (1213/30572 alleles) with 46 homozygotes in gnomAD v2.1.1. This case report/variant is not scored as it appears to be too frequent in the general population to cause disease. (Note: the variant is reported in the paper as c.1345G>A, Ala449Thr.)

Authors report that the c.1418G>A p.Arg473Gln variant (VUS in ClinVar) was identified in 1/130 cases and 0/200 controls in this study. This variant is reported at a frequency of 0.1% in non-Finnish European population (171/128456 alleles) with 0 homozygotes in gnomAD v2.1.1. This case report/variant is not scored as it appears to be too frequent in the general population to cause disease. (Note: the variant is reported in the paper as c.1586G>A, Arg529Gln.)

Authors report that the c.896A>G, p.Asn299Ser variant (VUS in ClinVar) was identified identified in 1/130 cases and 0/200 controls. This variant is reported at a frequency of 0.05% (59/128508 alleles) with 0 homozygotes in non-Finnish European population in gnomAD v2.1.1. The variant is unlikely to cause disease and therefore not scored. (Note: the variant is reported as c.1064A>C p.Asn355Ser in paper.)

member.rdfs:label: Monemi_Variant 1
member.detectionMethod: Linkage to WDR36 locus was analyzed with multipoint LOD of 4.9

evidence.dc:description: c.1964+2910T>C variant was observed in cases and controls, but the difference was statistically significant. c.1494+1111G>T (p = 0.011) and c.710+30C>T (noted risk factor in HTG; p = 0.268) had significantly higher frequency in cases vs. controls. A novel variant, c.460-650A>G, expected to impact splicing was identified only in cases; however, no functional evidence is available to confirm the impact of the variant. In conclusion, authors note that "WDR36 is only a subordinate factor playing a role of modifier in POAG, without consistency among races or populations".

caseCohort.detectionMethod: 23 exons and flanking introns of the WDR36 gene were screened by SOLiD NGS sequencing

controlCohort.detectionMethod: 23 exons and flanking introns of the WDR36 gene were screened by SOLiD NGS sequencing

evidence.dc:description: Authors note "WDR36 associated with sporadic HTG but not with NTG or JOAG. Results suggest a different mutation pattern of WDR36 in the Chinese population from other ethnic populations". While this study notes a significant association of the IVS5+30C>T variant with HTG, no significance was reported in the meta analysis that included this study.

The SNP c.710+30C>T was found to be marginally associates with POAG, but when the case cohort was divided into two groups (HTG and non-HTG), the variant was strongly associated with HTG; OR=1.216; 95% CI=1.064–2.306; p=0.002. No score is awarded for this individual study as the meta analysis that included this study found no statistical significance for any WDR36 variants in association with POAG.

caseCohort.detectionMethod: 10 SNPs across the WDR36 gene genotyped by PCR-RFLP. In addition, sequencing of exon 5 did not reveal any disease-causing variants.

controlCohort.detectionMethod: 10 SNPs across the WDR36 gene genotyped by PCR-RFLP. In addition, sequencing of exon 5 did not reveal any disease-causing variants.

evidence.dc:description:
Of the 118 probands from families with at least two members affected by POAG, 6 probands from juvenile-onset POAG families, and 108 control individuals
, 17% of POAG patients and 4% of control subjects. No statistical significance was noted for any variant. Authors note that "abnormalities in WDR36 alone are not sufficient to cause POAG…WDR36 may be a glaucoma modifier gene."

The meta analysis studied 5 SNPs in WDR36 for association with primary open angle glaucoma, high-tension glaucoma and normal-tension glaucoma: I264V, V727V, IVS5+30C>T, IVS16-30A>G, IVS3-113G>A. No significant association of any of the SNPs with POAG, HTG or NTG was reported in the meta analysis. For the variants, I264V: pooled-OR of 1.09 (95% CI: 0.94–1.28, P = .25, I2 = 0) and IVS5+30C>T: pooled-OR of 0.99 (95% CI: 0.71–1.39, P = .97, I2 = 77%). The authors note, "existing data in the literature do not support a significant role of WDR36 in the genetic susceptibility of POAG or its subtypes"

caseCohort.detectionMethod: This meta-analysis included 5 studies that genotyped individuals for WDR36 variants

controlCohort.detectionMethod: This meta-analysis included 5 studies that genotyped individuals for WDR36 variants

evidence.dc:description: 8 variants in 15 patients (12 with high IOP and 3 with low IOP) were determined to be disease-causing; however no functional evidence is available to score the evidence.

Mice with WDR36 variants do not show a glaucoma phenotype. Authors note the their results suggest an essential role for Wdr36 in the mouse retina. The evidence is not scored as the causal role of WDR36 variants in humans is not clearly established.

Intra-ocular pressure measurement was similar in WT and mutant mice. ~25% reduction in the peripheral retina thickness was observed for del605–607 mice compared with the WT mice. Disruption of synapses between RGC and amacrine cells was observed in del605-607 mice. RGC axon outgrowth was reduced by ∼60%.
evidence.rdfs:label: Chi_Wdr36 mouse

evidence.dc:description: The zebrafish model is noted to show a non-specific eye phenotype. In addition, the causal nature of WDR36 variants in human patients with glaucoma is not established. The evidence is not scored.

The only clear difference observed between wrd36 morphants and wdr36 mutants was that the phenotypes showed slightly earlier in development when using MOs. Loss of Wdr36 resulted in small head and eye phenotypes with progressive degeneration of the lens development. Gross phenotype of 6 dpf wdr36 mutants included small head and eye phenotypes, along with defects in gut development. Inflated swim bladder was absent. Lens opacity was also observed with incident light illumination of the eye. Mutants also showed large, dysmorphic nucleolus, and disruption of nucleolus led to activation of the p53 stress–response pathway.
evidence.rdfs:label: Skarie_Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: The study assessed the modifier effect of STI1 in the context of WDR36 variation; however, does not provide evidence for the function of WDR36.
The study does not provide evidence for the function of WDR36 protein.
evidence.rdfs:label: Footz_WDR36 modifier

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is not scored any points as the expression is ubiquitous.
Authors show using northern blot that WDR36 is expressed in ocular and extra-ocular tissues.
evidence.rdfs:label: Monemi_expression
